subject: Critical Thinking
title: The Gambler's Fallacy: Luck Doesn't Have Memory
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Gambler's Fallacy: Luck Doesn't Have Memory.

hook.text: A roulette wheel lands on red 10 times in a row. You bet on black because 'it's due.' The wheel doesn't remember.

buildup.text: The gambler's fallacy: believing that past random events affect future random events. They don't.

discovery.text: In 1913 at Monte Carlo, black hit 26 times straight. Gamblers lost millions betting on red, convinced it was overdue.

twist.text: The inverse exists too: the 'hot hand fallacy.' If a basketball player makes 5 shots, we expect a 6th.

climax.text: Each flip, spin, or roll is independent. Probability doesn't 'balance out' â€” that's a human invention.

punchline.text: The coin doesn't know what happened last time.

quiz.question: What is the gambler's fallacy?
options: Believing past random events affect future random events
Gambling more than you can afford
